newsitem.title: NORWAY: Statoil group recommended for Greenland oil licence.
newsitem.headline: Statoil group recommended for Greenland oil licence.

text.p: The joint council on mineral raw materials for Greenland has recommended the award of an exploration and production licence off the west of the island to a Statoil-led group, Den norske stats oljeselskap AS (Statoil) said on Thursday.
The group, which includes Phillips Petroleum and Dansk Olie og Gasproduktionm, is one of five applicants for acreage in the Fylla area, about 150 km west of Nuuk, capital of Greenland.
If the licence is approved, Greenland company Nunaoil will join the Statoil group and take a 15 percent stake.

After approval by the Greenland government and Denmark's energy ministry the award will be put before the Danish parliamentary committee for Greenland affairs later this year, according to Statoil's Status Weekly newsletter.
The Fylla licence will be the first for oil exploration off Greenland since the 1970s. Seismic surveys have identified interesting geological structures with oil and gas potential, Statoil said.
"This is a step further towards a final award in December," said exploration manager Vidar Larsen in Statoil Denmark. "But we're not celebrating until the licence has been granted."
Larsen said the area offered new challenges in hydrocarbon play.

"It involves new high-risk exploration models which also offer high potential. Water depths in the area descend to 1,500 metres and many of the technical and geological problems are the same as in the Voering Basin off mid-Norway," he said.
The exploration licence covers 9,487 square km, corresponding to about 17 Norwegian North Sea blocks.
